fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The collection of infinitary first-order formulas over a signature \Sigma is defined inductively by the following rules:

fr:ol.fr:li: For each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} and terms t_{1}\colon A_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}\colon A_{n}, R(t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}) is a formula.
For any two terms of the same sort s,t\colon A, s = t is a formula.
\top is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \wedge \psi is a formula.
\bot is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \vee \psi is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \Rightarrow \psi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula, then \lnot \varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x\colon A is a variable, then \exists x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x\colon A is a variable, then \forall x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigvee _{i \in I}\varphi _{i} is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigwedge _{i \in I}\varphi _{i} is a formula.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Fragments of this collection are defined as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: The collection of atomic formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 and 2.
The collection of Horn formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4.
The collection of regular formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4 and 9.
The collection of coherent formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6 and 9.
The collection of first-order formulas over \Sigma is inductive generated by 1 through 10.
The collection of geometric formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6, 9, and 11.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (first-order) signature \Sigma consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A collection of sorts.

A collection of function symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B where A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n},B are sorts. Unary (n = 0) function symbols are also called constant symbols.

A collection of relation symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} where A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} are sorts. Unary (n = 0) relation symbols are usually called atomic propositions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Each sort comes with a collection of variables. We assume that given any collection of variables of sort A, there is a variable of sort A not in the given collection.
Let \Sigma be a signature. The collection of (raw) terms over \Sigma is inductively generated by the following rules:

fr:ul.fr:li: Each variable x of sort A is a term of sort A.

Let us write t\colon A if t is a term of sort A. If f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B is a function symbol and t_{1}\colon A_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}\colon A_{n} are terms of corresponding sorts, then f(t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n})\colon B.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The collection of infinitary first-order formulas over a signature \Sigma is defined inductively by the following rules:

fr:ol.fr:li: For each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} and terms t_{1}\colon A_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}\colon A_{n}, R(t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}) is a formula.
For any two terms of the same sort s,t\colon A, s = t is a formula.
\top is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \wedge \psi is a formula.
\bot is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \vee \psi is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \Rightarrow \psi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula, then \lnot \varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x\colon A is a variable, then \exists x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x\colon A is a variable, then \forall x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigvee _{i \in I}\varphi _{i} is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigwedge _{i \in I}\varphi _{i} is a formula.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Fragments of this collection are defined as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: The collection of atomic formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 and 2.
The collection of Horn formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4.
The collection of regular formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4 and 9.
The collection of coherent formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6 and 9.
The collection of first-order formulas over \Sigma is inductive generated by 1 through 10.
The collection of geometric formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6, 9, and 11.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A context is a finite list of distinct variables. Recall that each variable has a specified sort. A context is said to be suitable for a formula (resp., term) if every free variable of that formula (resp., term) appears in the given context.
A sequent over a signature \Sigma is a formal expression of the form \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi , where \varphi and \psi are formulas and \Gamma is a context suitable for both \varphi and \psi .
An axiomatization of a theory \mathscr {T} over a signature \Sigma is a collection of sequents over \Sigma . These sequents are the (non-logical) axioms of (the given axiomatization of) \mathscr {T}.
Let h\colon M\to N be a homomorphism between \Sigma -structures in a Heyting category \mathcal {C}.

fr:ul.fr:li: The homomorphism h is called an embedding (alternatively, M is a substructure of N) if the square above is a pullback for all atomic formulas.
The homomorphism h is called an elementary embedding if the square above is a pullback for all first-order formulas.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1}\colon B_{1},\ldots ,x_{m}\colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma . Given a \Sigma -structure M in \mathcal {C}, the interpretation of a formula-in-context \Gamma .\varphi in M is a subobject {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) defined recursively on the structure of \varphi as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\top \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \wedge \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the intersection of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \vee \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the union of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \Rightarrow \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the Heyting implication {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \Rightarrow {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\lnot \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the Heyting negation of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the image of the following composite: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A) \xrightarrow {\pi } M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) where \pi is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\forall x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is \forall _{\pi }({\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M}), where \forall _{\pi } is the right adjoint associated with a Heyting category and \pi \colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A)\to M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigvee _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary union of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigwedge _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary intersection of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (first-order) signature \Sigma consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A collection of sorts.

A collection of function symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B where A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n},B are sorts. Unary (n = 0) function symbols are also called constant symbols.

A collection of relation symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} where A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} are sorts. Unary (n = 0) relation symbols are usually called atomic propositions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Each sort comes with a collection of variables. We assume that given any collection of variables of sort A, there is a variable of sort A not in the given collection.
